Nesrin Korkmaz a,⇑, Yusuf Ceylan b, Parham Taslimi a, Ahmet Karadağ c, Ali Savas Bülbül d, Fatih S en e,⇑ aDepartment of Biotechnology, Faculty of Science, Bartin University, 74100 Bartin, Turkey b Faculty of Science, Department of Molecular Biology and Genetics, Bartın University, 74100 Bartın, Turkey cDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Yozgat Bozok University, 66200 Yozgat, Turkey dKahramanmaras Sütçü _Imam University, Faculty of Science and Arts, Department of Biology, 46100 Kahramanmaras , Turkey e Sen Research Group, Biochemistry Department, Faculty of Arts and Science, Dumlupınar University, Evliya Çelebi Campus, 43100 Kütahya, Turkey

Keywords: Antidiabetic Anticholinergic Antiepileptic Corylus avellana (Hazelnut) Green synthesis Medical applications
46 47 48 49 50
a b s t r a c t
Powder technology covers many fields from medicine to material science. Especially easy synthesis of nano- and micro-sized particles and low-cost synthesis with non-toxic chemicals are essential. The ability to design nanoparticles according to the application area and desired features is an advantage for many applications. Nanoparticles biosynthesis is under research due to broad biomedical practise. To synthesize of silver nanoparticle from the plant extract, Corylus avellana (Hazelnut) leaves were utilized for bioreduction of silver nitrate. The plant extract is thoroughly mixed with silver nitrate solution, studied the synthesis of nanoparticles using UV–Vis spectroscopy. The nanoparticles were characterized by SEM and XRD-Pattern. XRD analysis proved that the size range of the nanoparticles was 32 nm. Scanning microscope images also demonstrate nanoparticles having spherical shape and a mean size between 9 nm and 50 nm. The antibacterial effect of AgNPs obtained from hazelnut leaves demonstrated antibacterial effect against all tested bacteria strains. The results demonstrated that the plant extract acts as a good bioreductant for the production of silver nanoparticles. This compound was good inhibitor of the a-glycosidase, human carbonic anhydrase I and II isoforms, and cholinesterase enzymes. The results were obtained with Ki values of 12.84 ± 0.41 µM for a-glycosidase, 27.94 ± 3.77 µM for hCA I, 36.12 ± 6.03 µM for hCA II, 47.05 ± 6.83 µM for BChE, and 53.94 ± 7.55 µM for AChE, respectively.
2020 Published by Elsevier B.V. on behalf of The Society of Powder Technology Japan. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nanotechnology offers the use of advanced technology and tools for the development and modification of biological systems and enables the emergence of inspiration factors and bio-compo nentsNanobiotechnology is a science that applies nano-scale techniques, principles, and products to the field of biotechnology. Uses biological principles and materials to obtain new systems to be developed using nanoscale. During some years, biological systems were familiar to create nanoparticles from microbes [1] and plants [2]. The microbial arbitrated synthesis procedures have some disadvantages, such as identification of potent strain, preservation of aseptic conditions for the abundant growth of microbes, probabilities of contamination and infection [3]. Also, the synthesis of
80
81
82
83
nanoparticles from microbes is comparatively expensive and time consuming than plants [4]. It needs about 2–3 days just for the growth of microorganisms.
So, by observing all the hurdles, researches focus their points on the plants’ extract. By utilization of the green chemistry process, different plant extracts experienced the capability of synthesizing the dissimilar metal nanoparticles especially silver, iron, gold, lead, palladium, and copper [5–7]. Amongst the different metal nanoparticles, silver nanoparticles were obtaining important potential in whole world, and the researcher publications are also enhancing day by day. However, silver nanoparticles were showed having best anticancer and antioxidant characteristics and could be settled as novel therapeutic agents [8]. Different research papers narrated different processes in accordance with nanoparticles synthesis, their identification techniques, and biological effects. Hazelnut belongs to the Betulaceae family within the Corylus genus. The term ‘‘hazelnut” is used interchangeably to collect all Corylus species. Corylus avellana was extensively known species that flour-

sections.heading: 2 N. Korkmaz et al. / Advanced Powder Technology xxx (xxxx) xxx
sections.text:
ished in Turkey, France, Italy, Spain, and the United States. Turkey is the leading producer of hazelnuts in the world. Nuts are widely used for fruit and shell trade.
Inhibition of enzymes such as cholinesterases, secretases, and monoaminoxidase have been targeted for the therapy of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). In particular, recent works have focused on cholinesterase inhibitors. Indeed, the prescribed AD drugs goal to enhance the amount of acetylcholine (ACh) in the brain by inhibiting cholinesterase enzymes. Thus, clinical utilize of cholinesterase inhibitor compounds is sometimes limited due to their harmful effects and moderate benefits to AD patients [9–12]. In clinical therapies, many potential drugs like Meglitinides, Sulfonylureas, Thiazolidinediones, Biguanides, and a-glycosidase inhibitors are utilized to control great blood sugar difficulties (hyperglycemia) [13,14]. Carbonic anhydrase (CA) enzymes are recorded in a variety of tissue cells where they participate in diverse important biochemical mechanisms like respiration, carbon dioxide, acid-base balance, and bone resorption, ion transport, ureagenesis, lipogenesis, gluconeogenesis, and electrolyte secretion [15]. Many CA enzymes involved in these mechaisms are important therapeutic aims with the potential to be activated/inhibited for the therapy of a range of disturbances like cancer, glaucoma, edema, obesity, epilepsy, and osteoporos [16,17].
In current study focused on green synthesis of AgNPs, which can be easily synthesized, made using renewable and non-toxic reductive and used for pharmaceutical purposes. (Fig. 1). Although high amounts are spent each year for the synthesis of substances used as biological agents, green synthesis nanoparticles are an essential alternative to powder technology synthesized for pharmaceutical purposes. Since hazelnut plants are generally used as fruit, green leaves belonging to this plant are in waste position. In present study, hazelnut leaves, which are agricultural wastes, have been used as bio-reducers and the paper has originality in terms of recycling and utilization of wastes. The purpose of the current research article is to synthesize silver nanoparticles using hazelnut plant leaf extract as a reducing agent for silver ions and to investigate their biological applications and also analyze the enzyme activity studies of AgNPs that is limited numer of papers. It especially contributes to the literature on the enzyme activity studies of silver nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of the plant extracts
sections.text: Hazelnut tree leaves were ground with the aid of liquid nitrogen and distilled water was added to the ground powder. The resulting extract was filtered using filter paper and left in the oven for some time to remove the solvent. The extract was then stored at 4 C for use in the synthesis of silver nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of silver nanoparticles
sections.text: 5 mL of hazelnut leaf extract was added to 95 mL of 1 mM silver nitrate solution and after stirring in the flask, it was allowed to incubate at 85 C for 40 min to monitor the color change which is indicative of nanoparticle formation (Fig. 2). The color of hazelnut leaf extract has changed from yellow to brown after adding the silver solution. A supernatant was utilized for the UV–vis spectrometric analysis and for the antibacterial activity [6,7]. The UV– vis spectrophotometric analysis results emphasized the presence and reduction of Ag in the applied samples. The solution was withheld in the dark to prevent any photochemical reactions during the experiment. The AgNPs were purified by centrifugation at 13,000 rpm for 5 min and collected for further characterization. The instruments for the characterization of silver nanoparticles were given in detail in supporting the information part.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of silver nanoparticles
sections.text: AgNPs synthesized using hazelnut leaf extract were analyzed by characterization techniques such as XRD, UV–vis, TEM. The absorption spectra of Ag NPs were determined using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (THERMO, Model Multiscaner spectrophotometer). AgNPs were found to have an absorption band between 300 nm and 540 nm. The crystal structure and average particle size of the AgNPs were calculated using XRD analysis. XRD analysis was performed using a powder X-ray diffractometer (Panalytical, ModelEmpyrean Advance). It was also analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (TESCAN, MAIA3 XMU) to observe the morphology and particle size of the AgNPs.

sections.heading: 2.4. Minimum inhibition concentration
sections.text:
To determine antibacterial features of AgNPs procured by hazelnut leaves, four gram ( ) (Salmonella infantis, Klebsiella pneumonia, Salmonella enteritidis ATCC 13075, Escherichia coli ATCC 25922) and four gram (+) (Enterococcus faecalis ATCC 29212, Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 25923, Staphylococcus epidermidis DSMZ 20044, Bacillus subtilis DSMZ 1971) were tested. All tested bacterial strains were provided by the Department of Molecular Biology and Genetic of Bartın University (Bartın, Turkey). Minimum inhibition concentration (MIC) was explained that inhibits bacterial growth under usual condition by [18]. All bacteria strain were inoculated to Luria Bertani broth, and bacterial growth was standardized to 0.5 McFarland turbidity (1.5x108 CFU/mL). Into all wells of 96 well plate, the growth medium was added, and solution at same value was put into first well. Indeed, the mixture was diluted from 5 mg/mL to 0,15625 mg/mL using 96-well microplate that was incubated at 37 C. Initial AgNPs concentration was adjudicated as a result of prestudy. Also, tetracycline that is broad-spetrum agents is used as a positive control. By UV–visible spectrum at

MIC is the lowest concentration which took to inhibit bacterial growth. The minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) identifies the lowest concentration that kills microorganisms.

sections.heading: 2.5. Enzymes studies
sections.text:
In this study, the effects of the compound on both carbonic anydrase isoenzymes b Verpoorte et al. [19] and using p-nitrophenyl acetate substrate (PNA) [20] spectrophotometrically at 348 nm in the laboratory and then recorded. On the other hand, the effects of this compound on AChE and BChE enzymes were studied according to the procedure of Ellman et al., And then the results were calculated and then written in the table [21]. Other sources have examined the results of enzymatic reaction using acetylthioline iodide and butyryloklin iodide as substrate for 412 nm wavelength results were recorded [22,23]. One of the choline esterase enzymes, the 5.5 Dithio-bis (2-nitro-benzoic) acid substrate, was used to measure the activity of the AChE enzyme [24]. Indeed, the effect of this compound on the a-glycosidase enzyme was studied according to the analysis of Tao et al. And was performed in vitro using the p-nitrophenyl-D-glycopyranoside (p-NPG) substrate [25]. For the antidiabetic study, first, 250 L of phosphate buffer was prepared and then this buffer (0.15 U / mL, pH 7.4) was mixed with 50 L of a homogenate solution. In addition, 50 LL of p-NPG was added to the final volume and again incubated at 33 C for 5 min. Absorbances were studied spectrophotometrically in the laboratory at 405 nm and the results were then calculated [26,27].

sections.heading: 3.1. UV–Visible absorption analysis
sections.text:
AgNO3 treated hazelnut leaf extract was visually observed. During this observation, a color change from green to brown was observed. According to the data in the literature, it was predicted that AgNPs were formed from this color change [28–30].
After completion of the reaction (after 40 min), the particle synthesis of AgNPs in the colloidal solution was monitored by UV–vis (Fig. 3). UV-spectroscopy has proven to be a beneficial method for
Please cite this article as: N. Korkmaz, Y. Ceylan, P. Taslimi et al., Biogenic nan matic activity, Advanced Powder Technology, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.202
the characterization of nanoparticles [31]. A strong peak was observed at about 430 nm for the nanoparticles synthesized in the UV–vis absorption spectrum. Observation of this peak is good evidence for metal nanoparticles of different sizes between 0 and 100 nm [32].

sections.heading: 3.2. XRD analysis
sections.text:
The crystal structure of the AgNPs was determined by X-ray diffraction. The XRD pattern obtained is shown in Fig. 4.
The assignment of Miller Indices (hkl) for the peak values of each maximum by indexing XRD data is given in Table 1 in detail. All the reflections correspond to pure silver metal with FCC (Face Centered Cubic) symmetry. The high intense peak for face centered cubic materials is generally (1 1 1) reflection, which is observed in the sample.
The average size of the AgNPs obtained was calculated using the Debye-Scherrer equation.

The particle size of AgNPs using the Scherrer equation was calculated to be approximately 32 nm. This value is consistent with AgNP particle sizes in the literature [33–35].
Five main peaks at 38.42 , 44.42 , 64.80 , 77.77 and 81.84 with respective interplanar spacing (d calculated) values of 2.34254, 2.03938, 1.43875, 1.22807 Å, and 1,17699 Å correspond to planes. Also other observed peaks were thought to belong to some organic residues present in the hazelnut leaf extract. These peaks correspond to 111, 200, 220 and 311 planes for silver nanoparticles indicate that the particles are crystalline in nature [34]. The sharp bands of Bragg’s peak authenticate that the particles are in the nanoregime and are stabilized by the reducing agents present in the leaf extract [35].
Also, compared with the standard silver powder diffraction card of Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS), silver file No. 04–0783. XRD analysis shows that the resulting particles are Face Centered Cubic AgNPs [36]. The Experimental Diffraction Angle [2h = 44.4229] and the Standard Diffraction Angle [2h = 44.3] are approximately the same [37].
Please cite this article as: N. Korkmaz, Y. Ceylan, P. Taslimi et al., Biogenic nan matic activity, Advanced Powder Technology, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.202
Additionally, the nanoparticles obtained according to X-Ray data are not pure AgNPs. The obtained nanoparticles consist of 71% pure Ag and 29% Ag2O. While three peaks at 44.42 , 64.80 , and 77.77 relate to Ag, the peak at 38.42 concern with the peaks present as a mixture of pure Ag and Ag2O. The crystalline peaks at 2h = 28.12 and 46.55 can be listed as 3.17283 and 1.95086 planes of organic phases, respectively [38–40].

sections.heading: 3.3. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) study of AgNPs
sections.text:
Over the last 20 years, high resolution microscopy techniques have been rapidly developed to learn about nano materials. One of these techniques is scanning electron microscopy (SEM). SEM is an imaging method that can solve particle shape, size, particle distribution, nano, and micro-level surface morphology [41–43]. At this stage, SEM images were taken to measure particle morphology and size of nanoparticles obtained using nut leaf extract as a reducing agent. The data obtained from scanning electron microscopy showed distinct shapes and sizes of nanoparticles (Fig. 5ab). The images were taken at 500 kx, and 200 kx magnifications show different particle sizes ranging from 9 nm to 50 nm. Furthermore, the SEM images obtained at this magnification show that the Ag nanoparticles are coated with a layer about 5 nm thick. This second layer is thought to originate from phenolic compounds (3- caffeoylquinic acid, 5-caffeoylquinic acid, caffeoyltartaric acid, pcoumaroyltartaric acid, myricetin 3-rhamnoside, quercetin 3- glycoside, quercetin 3-rhamnoside and kaempferol 3- rhamnoside) found in hazelnut leaf extract. Similar images have been reported in the literature [44].
STEM analysis images of the synthesized AgNPs report more accurate results regarding the size of the nanoparticles. Fig. 5c shows 500-fold magnified STEM images of Ag NPs synthesized with the help of hazelnut leaf extract. STEM image showed that AgNPs synthesized using hazelnut leaf extract had a particle size between 8 and 23 nm and these values are consistent with similar studies in the literature [45]. Depending on the application, a large

sections.heading: 3.4. Antibacterial activity
sections.text:
The antibacterial properties of AgNPs was studied against eight bacteria strains. For all bacteria, AgNPs displayed antibacterial activity (Fig. 6). Except for S. infantis, AgNPs showed both MIC and MBC activity against tested bacteria (Fig. 7). The MIC and MBC value were respectively at 0.625 mg/mL and 1.25 mg/mL against E. faecalis, B. subtilis, S. aureus and E. coli. Especially, the results of AgNPs against Gram (+) bacteria wa similar to tetracycline.
Due to its antibacterial effect, silver has been widely used in wound dressings, antiseptic creams, food depots, paint removal, textile coatings, pharmaceuticals and many environmental applications. Many researchers have studied the antibacterial properties of AgNPs to clarify their mechanism. Ivask et al. investigated the mechanism of toxicity of different sizes of AgNPs against bacteria. The mechanism of toxicity was studied at the genome level using E. coli bacterial strains and reported that toxicity was related to ligand and surface coating [47]. Due to their physicochemical properties, AgNPs generally cause damage to the cell wall and membrane structure of bacteria and cause the death of bacterial cells. Silver ions act as lewis acid against sulfur and phosphorus biomolecules found in bacterial cells and lewis acid-base interaction is
Please cite this article as: N. Korkmaz, Y. Ceylan, P. Taslimi et al., Biogenic nan matic activity, Advanced Powder Technology, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.202
observed. The binding of AgNPs to cell wall and membrane bring about the structural defect as cytoplasm shrinking, membrane disjunction [48–50]. Additionally, it has also been shown that the antibacterial activity of AgNPs is caused by oxidative stress due to the release of free radicals (ROS, RNS, etc.) [51]. Gram (+) bacteria such as S. aureus, E. faecalis, B. subtilis, and S. epidermidis used in this study have peptidoglycan structure with pores that can facilitate diffusion of AgNPs into cell-induced cell damage and cell death [52]. Dipankar and Murugan in their study, AgNPs synthesized with the help of Iresine herbstii leaf, reported that P. aeruginosa, K. pneumoniae, S. aureus, E. faecalis, and E. coli and against similar bacterial species they have high antibacterial activity [53]. In another study, they investigated the antibacterial activity of AgNPs synthesized using Clitoria ternatea plant extract against Gram ( ) and Gram (+) bacteria [54]. Their study presented that AgNPs is a good antibacterial agent. The penetration of NPs was promoted in Gram-negative bacteria due to thin layer of peptidoglycan. Ag+ ions vigorously bind to thiol group of enzymes and inhibit them. As a result, it has been reported that AgNPs inhibit bacterial growth or kill bacteria [55].

sections.heading: 6 N. Korkmaz et al. / Advanced Powder Technology xxx (xxxx) xxx
sections.text:
nal, inhibitor compounds targeting hCA IV, II, XIV, and XII are utilized as diuretics, in the management edema, as antiglaucoma agents, antiepileptic drugs [56]. The hCA I isoform was inhibited by this compound in low micromolar levels, the Ki of which recorded 27.94 ± 3.77 µM. The acetazolamide (AZA), as Standard inhibitor of CAs, showed Ki value of 34.61 ± 3.71 µM against hCA I. The hCA I inhibition effect of this compound was found to be the greater than that of acetazolamide, which was a clinically standard CA inhibitor (Table 2 and Fig. 8). For hCA I, IC50 values of AZA as control and nanosilver compound the following order: nanosilver (24.85 µM, r2: 0.9253) < AZA (31.93 µM, r2: 0.9875). Against the physiologically dominant isoform hCA II, the compound demonstrated Ki of 36.12 ± 6.03 µM (Table 2 and Fig. 8). This compound had high inhibition effect toward hCA II. On the other hand, standard compound AZA showed Ki of 46.16 ± 6.88 µM against hCA II. For hCA II, IC50 values of AZA as positive control and nanosilver compound the following order: nanosilver (30.13 µM, r2: 0.9463)
Please cite this article as: N. Korkmaz, Y. Ceylan, P. Taslimi et al., Biogenic nan matic activity, Advanced Powder Technology, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.202
< AZA (40.87 µM, r2: 0.9483). CA inhibitors show numerous bioactivities including are associated to many diseases such as glaucoma, obesity, cancer, epilepsy and osteoporosis. CA I, and CA II are involved in important metabolic functions such as gas exchange, and ion transport [57].
In the last decade, research for AD treatment has focused on developing cholinergic neurotransmission in brain cells. This mechanism is largely based on the cholinergic hypothesis, which has prompted evaluations on cholinesterase enzymes inhibitors (ChEIs) that increase the central cholinergic neurotransmission by inhibiting ACh degradation. AD treatment includes a cholinergic mechanism that acts on inhibitors of cholinesterase enzymes (ChEIs) and also increases central cholinergic neurotransmission by inhibiting ACh degradation [58]. As can be seen from the results obtained in Table 2 and Fig. 8, this compound effectively inhibited AChE, with Ki value of 53.94 ± 7.55 µM. For AChE, IC50 values of TAC as positive control and this compound the following order:

Additionally, the nanosilver compound effectively inhibited BChE, with Ki value of 47.05 ± 6.83 µM. AChEIs like donepezil are approved by the Drug Administration and United States Food for the treatment of AD, and have clinical trial data supporting their utilize in Parkinson’s disease and vascular dementia [59].
a-Glycosidase inhibitor compounds show a 10,000-fold greater affinity to carbohydrate-binding sites than oligosaccharide and
Please cite this article as: N. Korkmaz, Y. Ceylan, P. Taslimi et al., Biogenic nan matic activity, Advanced Powder Technology, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.202
polysaccharide molecules. Polysaccharides and oligosaccharides cannot be converted into simple sugars like monosaccharides that the body can absorb [60]. Thus, a-glycosidase inhibitors are significant drugs to inhibit the assimilation of carbohydrate molecules in the intestine cells, can be utilized to therapy of T2DM, and impaired glucose tolerance. Therefore, these hypoglycemic factors are applied to patients with early diabetes or combined with other drugs. Miglitol and Acarbose are standard a-glycosidase inhibitor compounds which utilized to clinically treat patients with T2DM [61]. sections.heading: 8 N. Korkmaz et al. / Advanced Powder Technology xxx (xxxx) xxx
sections.text:
0.9664) < ACR (12.98 µM, r2: 0.9872). For enzyme glycosidase, nanosilver compound has IC50 value of 10.75 µM and Ki value of 12.84 ± 0.41 µM (Table 2 and Fig. 8). The results have documented that all of these derivatives have shown the inhibitory effects of aglycosidase efficient acarbose (IC50: 12.98 µM) as a standard glycosidase inhibitor. The novel nanoparticles used in our study showed inhibition effects on hCA I, and II isoenzymes and AChE, BChE and a-glycosidase enzymes activities at low micromolar concentrations. We believe that these results may be useful in the synthesis of new AChE, BChE, alpha glycosidase, and CA isoenzyme inhibitors and in the development of drugs for the treatment of some diseases [61].

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: The AgNPs are applied in various applications such as cancer diagnosis and treatment as well as use as drug carriers. The synthesis of these AgNPs with environmentally friendly reducing agents is important for the entire ecosystem. Biosynthesis has been a more preferred method for the synthesis of silver nanoparticles compared to conventional methods using harmful reducing agents such as sodium borohydride, trisodium citrate, free aldehyde, ketone groups, and organic substances. In addition, present study is concentrated on green synthesis without toxic chemicals and recycle of agricultural waste. Biosynthetic AgNPs from nut leaves indicated their presence in the UV–vis absorption spectrum as a strong peak at about 430 nm. XRD analysis proved that the size of the nanoparticles was 32 nm, while STEM images showed that these nanoparticles had a spherical shape and an average size between 9 nm and 50 nm. AgNPs demonstrated an essential antibacterial effect against all bacterial strains tested. AgNPs could be applied as a silver bandage of wounds, pomade containing AgNPs, and additionally as an eco-friendly antibacterial agent for every field in need. Also, we investigated the compound for their inhibition activities against hCA isoforms (I, II), a-glycosidase, and cholinesterases (AChE, BChE). As a result of this study, this compound showed inhibition at the micromolar levels against these enzymes. The synthesized compound was a good inhibitor for hCA I, II isoenzymes, a-glycosidase, and AChE/BChE enzymes, respectively. This type of compound may form 20 the cornerstone for the development of novel antiglaucoma, antiepileptic, anticholinesterase, and anticancer drugs.

metadata.abstractText: Powder technology covers many fields from medicine to material science. Especially easy synthesis of nanoand micro-sized particles and low-cost synthesis with non-toxic chemicals are essential. The ability to design nanoparticles according to the application area and desired features is an advantage for many applications. Nanoparticles biosynthesis is under research due to broad biomedical practise. To synthesize of silver nanoparticle from the plant extract, Corylus avellana (Hazelnut) leaves were utilized for bioreduction of silver nitrate. The plant extract is thoroughly mixed with silver nitrate solution, studied the synthesis of nanoparticles using UV–Vis spectroscopy. The nanoparticles were characterized by SEM and XRD-Pattern. XRD analysis proved that the size range of the nanoparticles was 32 nm. Scanning microscope images also demonstrate nanoparticles having spherical shape and a mean size between 9 nm and 50 nm. The antibacterial effect of AgNPs obtained from hazelnut leaves demonstrated antibacterial effect against all tested bacteria strains. The results demonstrated that the plant extract acts as a good bioreductant for the production of silver nanoparticles. This compound was good inhibitor of the a-glycosidase, human carbonic anhydrase I and II isoforms, and cholinesterase enzymes. The results were obtained with Ki values of 12.84 ± 0.41 μM for a-glycosidase, 27.94 ± 3.77 μM for hCA I, 36.12 ± 6.03 μM for hCA II, 47.05 ± 6.83 μM for BChE, and 53.94 ± 7.55 μM for AChE, respectively. 2020 Published by Elsevier B.V. on behalf of The Society of Powder Technology Japan. All rights reserved.
